evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident withstands potential defeaters within the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including dynamic and interim factors captured in hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations, reflecting typical procedural variances during the specified interim phase.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim scope.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and timely warnings preventing the incident, or if the incident was solely due to procedural deviation without communication failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H2 show communication among crew during pushback, but H8 indicates a lack of effective warning signals and no warning of impending collision, supporting communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication failure or procedural deviation was primary cause

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including dynamic and interim factors captured in hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without breakdown
If procedural deviations or environmental deficiencies better explained the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 directly describe communication and coordination among crew and support that breakdowns align with key features in the incident, distinguishing coordination failure from procedural deviation and marking deficiencies.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in extent of communication effectiveness and possible procedural factors
